Class BaseToolBar

              +--javax.swing.JComponent

                    +--javax.swing.JToolBar
                          |
                          +--com.esri.mo2.ui.tb.BaseToolBar
All Implemented Interfaces:
Accessible, ImageObserver, MenuContainer, Serializable, SwingConstants
Direct Known Subclasses:
BaseToolBar, LayerToolBar, MapNotesToolBar, MeasureGeocodeToolBar, ProjectToolBar, SelectionToolBar, ZoomPanToolBar
public abstract class BaseToolBar
extends JToolBar

A base class that provides common functionality for ToolBars. Subclasses using these methods must,

  • construct a collection of actions within the addDefaultActions method and
  • invoke addDefaultActions() within a constructor or whenever appropriate.
In order to use a ToolBar, you must first associate it with a Map using the setMap method.

Some ToolBars may work specifically with a "selected" Layer/button group, in which case the setSelectedLayer/setButtonGroup method should be used respectively.

If any run-time changes are made to a ToolBar instance, you must call the refresh method to rebuild the user interface. When refresh() is invoked, all the Actions that are designated as "button" Actions are reconstructed.

Note: Not all Actions need to be buttons - you can add any kind of Component to represent an Action.

See Also:
Serialized Form

Constructor Detail

BaseToolBar

public BaseToolBar()
Constructs a BaseToolBar object with no associated map. You must call the setMap method before attempting to use a ToolBar.

Note: Only subclasses can invoke this constructor.

Method Detail

addDefaultActions

protected abstract void addDefaultActions()
Constructs the default actions.

Subclasses must implement this method to construct all the appropriate Actions and set the value of the actions member appropriately.

See Also:
actions

refresh

public void refresh()
Recreates and repaints the ToolBar user interface.

This method destroys all the ToolBar button groups before recreating them. You need to invoke this method after adding or removing Actions from a ToolBar.

public void updateUI()
Overrides javax.swing.JToolBar.updateUI(). This method calls the updateIcons() method on the collection of Actions.
